journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: On sequencing the feature extraction techniques for online damage characterization

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Civil Engineering and Engineering Mechanics, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, USA
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC, USA

author-notes.corresp: Sourav Banerjee, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of South Carolina, Columbia, SC 29208, USA. Email: banerjes@cec.sc.edu

abstract.p: The current state of the health-monitoring technology lacks a generalized and definitive approach to the identification and localization of mechanical damage in structural materials. In past decades, several signal-processing tools have been used for solving different health-monitoring problems but the commutability of the tools between different problems has been restricted. The fundamental reasons for this shortcoming have never been investigated in detail. A thorough study is presented in this article employing almost all promising feature extraction tools on a representative problem—a plate with rivet holes. The cracks around rivet holes in a joint panel of a steel truss bridge are very difficult to detect. Although well established, Lamb wave–based nondestructive evaluation techniques are revisited and new tools are developed to address this issue. The simulation of scattered ultrasonic wave field is carried out using the finite element method. This ultrasonic wave field is further analyzed to evaluate the integrity of the structure using various feature extraction techniques. The joint time–frequency–energy representation is obtained from ultrasonic signals recorded at various locations on the plate (joint panel) and used to extract damage-sensitive features. Those features were then used to formulate a new damage parameter for better visualization of the crack. The results are shown to demonstrate the comparative effectiveness of these techniques. It is concluded that any particular feature extraction technique cannot detect all possible sizes and orientations of the crack. It is suggested that the statistical occurrence and pattern of the crack must be visualized through few selective feature extraction techniques in a sequence.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Structural failures are often attributed to a number of factors, such as uncertainties in loading conditions, material deterioration, environmental conditions, and so on. The unavoidability of such incidence always motivated researchers to think about automated damage prognosis in structures to facilitate real-time supervision. Such endeavors are now materializing and gaining popularity as a result of increased public awareness and demand for high safety measures. In nondestructive evaluation community, this automated diagnosis and prognosis technique is known as the structural health monitoring (SHM).

In the last couple of decades, several investigations (Alleyne and Cawley, 1992a, 1992b; Cawley and Alleyne, 1996; Chimenti, 1997; Hu et al., 2007; Lee and Staszewski, 2003; Raghavan and Cesnik, 2007; Vemula and Norris, 1997) have carried out guided wave-based nondestructive evaluation (NDE) techniques where the structure under inspection is excited by a short diagnostic pulse wave that travels through the structure interacting with its internal configurations. The structural response is then monitored with the help of a network of sensors placed on the structure. Based on these response data, the health of the structure is assessed. The particular process described above is well established. However, a missing link that is not available in the process is a standard protocol in quantifying the degree of damage in the materials. Different techniques for damage diagnosis and quantification were reported in the literatures. However, a standard process by utilizing the pros and cons of those techniques in a proper sequence has not been reported. This is the motivation of this article. In this article, an automated multitechnique diagnostics (AMTD) scheme is reported for automated damage diagnosis and quantification.

The elastic waves travelling in a bounded medium such as a thin plate forms complex pattern of waves commonly known as the guided Lamb wave contained within the wave guide. These guided waves propagate long distances with low attenuation providing cost-effective monitoring techniques. The Lamb waves interact with anomalies producing reflected and scattered waves in different directions. The individual characteristics of different structural damage influence the scattered wave field. A thorough analysis of these scattered ultrasonic wave field signals is used to extract damage information to characterize the anomalies. The Lamb wave–based NDE technique has shown to be effective in detecting a wide variety of anomalies, such as voids, flaws, porosity, delamination, cracking, debonding, corrosion, and so on (Cegla et al., 2008; Clezio et al., 2002; Fromme and Sayir, 2002; Grahn, 2003; Guo and Cawley, 1992; Lu et al., 2008; Mckeon and Hinders, 1999; Roh and Chang, 1995; Rose, 2002; Su et al., 2006; Tan et al., 1995; Tang and Henneke, 1991; Wang et al., 1999; Wilcox et al., 2001). In the past, researchers have investigated if using Lamb waves in the frequency range varying from 1 to 10 MHz, the anomalies of dimensions of few millimeters can be precisely detected (Kessler, 2002). However, the contamination due to ambient noise, temperature variation, material anisotropy, and the complex dispersive nature of Lamb waves exacerbates the process of interpretation of these signals for damage diagnosis. The existence of multiple modes makes the damage identification even more challenging. Some of these issues although might be addressed, for example, by restricting the frequency of actuation so that only fundamental modes are excited and allowed to propagate or by employing wedge transducers to excite only desired modes, eventually we require a comprehensive in-depth analysis of ultrasonic signals for better understanding and interpretation. Contrary to the traditional NDE techniques, the SHM exploits the possibility of reducing human intervention by putting the sensors directly on the structure. Also for SHM applications, the preferred frequency band of investigation is relatively low, between 100 and 500 kHz. In the SHM applications, the attached sensors to the structures cannot be moved or replaced easily. Generally, the sensors are degraded over time and their calibration for reliable damage estimation during their life time is expected to be affected. The calibration is not a concern for traditional NDE applications because the ultrasonic probes can be calibrated offline in that case. In spite of these uncertainties associated with the permanently attached sensor network, reliable estimation of damage location, size, and orientation is necessary for having confidence on the SHM system. Many damage detection schemes have been proposed in the literature for solving different targeted applications. However, the effectiveness of various techniques for a specific application has not been studied extensively. This study would help SHM in two ways: (1) it will help to decide the sequence of the feature extraction (FE) tools that are necessary for particular damage detection problem, and thus, it will demonstrate the possibility of desired AMTD scheme; and (2) employment of the AMTD for a particular problem could increase the probability of detection (POD) of the target application.

In reality, the presence of any form of structural damage does affect the propagating ultrasonic wave field. The damage detection capability depends on how well the variation in propagating ultrasonic wave field can be associated with the characteristics of the damage such as location, size, and orientation. The signal processing provides an in-depth insight of a raw signal in terms of some critical parameters, for example, amplitude, frequency, time of flight, phase, and so on. The success of any damage prognosis scheme depends largely on the proper processing of captured ultrasonic signals.

In this investigation, a variety of digital signal processing (DSP) techniques have been tried out. The conceptual and theoretical aspects of the DSP can be found in earlier publications (Choi and Williams, 1989; Huang, 1998; Niethammer et al., 2001; Stockwell et al., 1996). The advancement of computational power in last couple of decades has led to unprecedented increase in the number of signal-processing methods that are now available in the DSP. The choice of appropriate method is also a challenge in dealing with signals.

The key objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of ultrasonic elastic waves in characterizing damage such as cracks in and around the rivet holes in a steel bridge joint panel. A comparative appraisal of popular signal-processing techniques in damage diagnosis is also presented here.

sec.title: Statement of the problem
sec.p: A joint panel in a steel truss bridge is investigated for localized small-scale damages such as cracking through numerical simulations. The configuration of the problem is shown in Figure 1. Here, it is necessary to mention that irrespective of the specific application we kept the problem geometry general enough so that this study could address problems for different other applications. The joint panel has five rivet holes of diameter 0.75 in (1.9 cm). The thickness of the panel is taken as 0.25 in (0.635 cm). The panel is assumed to be made of isotropic and homogeneous steel of density 7850 kg/m3. Young’s modulus and Poisson’s ratio for steel are 200×109 Pa and 0.33, respectively. Several crack lengths and orientations around the rivet holes are considered and listed in Table 1.

caption.p: Geometry of the modeled steel rivet joint plate.

sec.title: Problem modeling
sec.p: The structural integrity of the joint panel is evaluated from the scattered ultrasonic wave field. Both experimental and pure analytical studies are often complex and time consuming, which makes the Lamb wave–based damage detection a challenging task for real-life problems. The finite element method (FEM)-based approach is adopted in this study due to its versatility in handling complex geometrical configuration problems. In this article, the simulation work is carried out using commercially available software COMSOL Multi-Physics (Multiphysics, 2008).

The steel joint panel is idealized as a thin plate. Therefore, a plane stress condition can be assumed. The joint panel was modeled with traction-free boundary conditions on all surfaces except on one side (the corner edge of the L-shaped section, see Figure 1) where zero displacement condition was imposed. The lead zirconate titanate (PZT) actuator positioned at point A (x = 22.85 cm, y = 1.27 cm) on the panel is simulated by imposing in-plane radial displacement at point A with five-cycle short pulse signal of the form
where wc is the central frequency, and p and t0 are constants.

The Lamb wave propagates with multiple modes, either symmetric or anti-symmetric. The number of wave modes increases as the frequency-thickness product increases. To avoid the complexity arising from multiple modes, the analysis is often restricted to the fundamental modes only, for example, S0 and A0. Experimentally, this is carried out by limiting the frequency-thickness value below 2.0 MHz-mm for steel plate. Figure 2 shows the dispersion curves for a thin steel plate. The central frequency of the Lamb wave was set at 250 kHz to have a frequency-thickness product as 0.25 × 6.35 = 1.59 MHz-mm that is less than 2.0 MHz-mm. The Lamb wave response has been recorded with sampling frequency of 12.5 MHz at locations S1 (1.27, 8.89), S2 (15.24, 8.89), S3 (30.48, 8.89), and S4 (44.45, 8.89).

caption.p: Lamb wave dispersion curves for a steel plate.

sec.p: For an accurate simulation of the ultrasonic wave field by finite element technique using COMSOL (Multiphysics, 2008), the FE mesh size was chosen such that there are at least 10 inter-nodal intervals per unit wavelength of the induced wave. The ultrasonic guided wave propagating with a central frequency of 250 kHz in steel thus requires a mesh size of 0.20 cm (=0.08 in) that was adopted for the entire simulation. For achieving sampling frequency of 12.5 MHz, the sampling period was set at 8×10−8 s. For checking convergence, the simulation was carried out twice for a sample problem with element size of 0.08 and 0.1 in. The variation in peak stresses generated by the S0 mode from these two analyses was found to be less than 1% thus guaranteeing convergence.

sec.title: Lamb wave
sec.p: The theory of Lamb wave propagation in a plate is well-known. In the context of present study, a brief précis is presented here. The Lamb waves are dispersive, travel long distances, and have multiple modes. There are two fundamental modes—namely longitudinal (symmetric) and flexural (anti-symmetric) modes. The equation of Lamb wave dispersion in a plate-like structure is written as follows.
For symmetric mode
and for anti-symmetric mode
where k = ωcL, η=(k2−kP2)1/2,β=(k2−kS2)1/2,kP = ω/cP, kS = ω/cS, and 2h is the thickness of the plate.

Equations (2) and (3) are to be solved simultaneously. Due to the complexity of these equations a closed form expression for the roots of these equations cannot be obtained. However, the roots can be found numerically. These roots give the dispersion curves, that is, phase velocity vs. frequency curves as shown in Figure 2.

sec.title: Signal-processing technique
sec.p: The large quantity of time history data makes it difficult to bring out any valuable information for damage detection. It requires extracting essential features from numerous recorded data. The well-known Fourier transform analysis provides a tool to extract the frequency content of a time history signal. This is helpful in analyzing spectral component of the signal. But the drawback of the Fourier transform analysis is that the time information is completely lost. The time–frequency representation (TFR) of a time history signal provides a more effective analysis tool.

In this investigation, the analysis tools used are given as follows—the short-time Fourier transform (STFT), the wavelet transform (WT), the Wigner–Ville distribution transform (WVD), the Hilbert–Huang transform (HHT), the Choi–Williams distribution transform (CWD), and the S-transform (ST). These TFRs have been used for extracting damage-sensitive features from raw signals. The reason for considering several techniques is to investigate which technique can deliver consistent and reliable information about the damage. Also, a comparative discussion about merits and demerits of each of these six TFR techniques in damage assessment is provided. The ultimate goal of this investigation is to recommend a sequence of these techniques that would be able to degenerate the information on crack location, size, and orientation. These techniques are briefly described below.

sec.title: STFT
sec.p: The Fourier analysis in its modified form overcomes the limitation of loss of temporal information forming the basis for STFT technique. In this technique, the time information within small section of the signal (window) is transformed into its frequency content. The STFT thus presents a compromise between the time and frequency resolution. It provides a tool to choose the needed precision in either time or frequency. Mathematically, the STFT of a time history signal x(t) is defined as (Niethammer et al., 2001)

where w(t) is the window function and x(t) is the signal to be transformed. The spectrogram (TFR) is then defined as energy density spectrum from the STFT as E(τ,ω)=|X(ω,t)|2. In the STFT, the wide window size gives better frequency resolution at the cost of time resolution and vice versa. The drawback is once a window size is selected, it remains the same for all frequencies.

sec.title: WT
sec.p: This forms the next logical stage in which the window of varying size is used. It gives good frequency resolution at lower frequencies and good time resolution at higher frequencies. As an improvement over STFT, the windowed function is replaced with mother wavelet function ψ(t) with continuous scaling and shifting. This wavelet ensures much better time–frequency resolution. Mathematically, the WT of a time history signal x(t) is defined as (Niethammer et al., 2001)

where “a” is scaling and “b” denotes the time shift parameter. The parameter ‘a’ is inversely proportional to frequency (i.e. smaller “a” parameter value corresponds to higher frequency). The correspondence between the scale factor “a” and the frequency is evaluated using the following relation

where a is a scale, Δ is the sampling period, Fc is the center frequency of a wavelet in Hertz (used for “db4” as 0.71429), and Fa is the pseudo-frequency corresponding to the scale a (in Hz). Using equation (6), the approximate values of scale have been evaluated for their respective pseudo-frequencies as shown in Table 2:.

The wavelet analysis produces a time scale view of signal, with scaling and shifting. The spectrogram (TFR) in this case is defined as the energy density spectrum E(a,b)=|X(a,b)|2. It is capable of revealing hidden aspects of signal such as trends, break down points, and so on, which might possibly be missed by other techniques.

sec.title: WVD
sec.p: The Wigner–Ville distribution of a signal x(t) is defined as (Niethammer et al., 2001)

where x(t) is the signal to be transformed and x* is the complex conjugate of x. The advantage of this type of distribution over STFT or continuous WT (CWT) is that it can efficiently locate sharp impulses; however, it has some limitations in the form appearance of the interference term.

sec.title: HHT
sec.p: In this technique, for a signal x(t) a complex signal z(t) = x(t) +jx′(t) is first evaluated. The x′(t) is obtained by performing a Hilbert transform on signal x(t). The Hilbert transform only changes the phase of x(t) by π/2 keeping the magnitude same. The instantaneous frequency f(t) is obtained by (Huang, 1998)
where φ(t) is the phase of complex signal z(t) evaluated by ϕ(t)=tan−1(x′(t)/x(t)).

However, this requires x(t) to be well-behaved and symmetrical about the midpoint of the envelopes of maximum amplitude and minimum amplitude, which is not the case for most practical problems. Huang et al. (1998) suggested a new method called empirical mode decomposition method by which a signal can be decomposed into several intrinsic mode functions (IMF), which upon addition give back the original signal with marginal errors. These IMF have all the necessary properties needed to be operated by the Hilbert transform and hence can provide instantaneous frequency f(t) for each IMF. Furthermore, the Hilbert energy spectrum corresponding to instantaneous frequency and time is then obtained by E(f,t)=A2(f,t) where A(f, t) is the amplitude of the complex signal z(t).

sec.title: CWD
sec.p: This transform was proposed by Choi and Williams (1989). This distribution is a Cohen’s class distribution that uses exponential kernel function to suppress the interference cross terms. The Choi–Williams distribution of a signal x(t), is defined as

where Φ(η,τ)=exp[−(ητ)2/σ], σ is an adjustable parameter used for fixing frequency resolution as well as suppressing the cross terms. For a smaller value of σ, more cross terms are suppressed but that also affects other terms. Therefore, a compromised value of σ should be used. As can be seen when σ→∞, the exponential kernel function Φ(η,τ) approaches unity that actually makes it Wigner–Ville distribution.

sec.title: ST
sec.p: It forms a basis for a combination of both STFT as well as CWT. The ST of a signal can be seen as a modified STFT with a Gaussian window of varying width and height as a function of frequency or as a modified CWT with phase correction in the mother wavelet. However, the modified wavelet skips the wavelet’s admissibility criteria of zero mean, and hence, it is not exactly a CWT. The ST of a signal x(t), as given by Stockwell et al. (1996) is

The TFR are obtained from these six candidate FE tools and then used to extract features along the time axis in a vector form consisting of energy density values corresponding to frequencies 125, 250, and 500 kHz around the central frequency (250 kHz) of the actuating burst signal.

sec.title: Damage quantification and FE
sec.p: The most critical and difficult step of damage detection is to identify the parameter of the signal that is most sensitive to damage. This parameter can then be investigated to predict the extent of damage in the structure. This process of identifying and extracting the damage-sensitive properties is called FE. A number of methods have been developed over the years for quantifying the damage using extracted features. A single parameter called damage parameter (DP) is formulated to indicate the severity of damage in a structure. In this study, the signal energy-based features are extracted to derive DP. In order to do this, the signal energy spectra in joint TFR are obtained by various techniques discussed in the “S-transform” section.

The proposed DP is given in equation (11). It is the ratio of the relative change in the energy spectrum magnitude caused by damage to that of the baseline energy spectrum obtained from the healthy structure at three different frequencies.
The joint TFR using different methods and techniques mentioned in “S-transform” section is used to formulate the DP as proposed below

where DPf=|BfT(τ).Bf(τ)−DfT(τ).Df(τ)BfT(τ).Bf(τ)|, Bf(τ) is the baseline signal or the wave signal obtained from the healthy structure, and Df(τ) is the wave signal obtained from the cracked plate. The superscript T indicates transpose of the respective vector. Equation (11) has been formulated by considering features around the central frequency of actuation signal (250 kHz) where the most of the signal energy is concentrated. The features associated with the frequencies below and above this central frequency are also taken into consideration to accommodate any shift in signal energy that can happen due to the presence of any kind of anomalies along the wave path. The features corresponding to 125 (half of 250 kHz) and 500 kHz (double of 250 kHz) are considered in the proposed DP expression.
For the HHT technique, the DPf components are evaluated using the intrinsic mode function with highest spectral energy.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The schematic diagram of the problem geometry is shown in Figure 1. A rectangular steel panel of size 45.7 cm × 10.2 cm × 0.635 cm containing five circular rivet holes of diameter 1.9 cm has been sliced out of an L-shaped joint panel and investigated. The investigation is carried out by finite element simulation using COMSOL Multi-Physics (Multiphysics, 2008). The radial cracks of different orientations and size around the central rivet hole H2 are considered in the finite element model. The homogeneous steel panel (density, longitudinal, and shear wave speeds, 7.9 g/cm3, 5.98 km/s, and 3.3 km/s, respectively) has the traction-free boundary conditions on all surfaces except one surface (the surface that is connected to the L-shaped panel). On this surface, the zero displacement boundary condition is imposed. Four distinct damage cases are analyzed. Radial cracks of size 2 and 4 mm around the central rivet hole have been considered for two different orientations, for example, in the direction of the y-axis (at 0° orientation) and at 135° orientation measured clockwise from the y-axis. In order to simplify the study, only the central rivet hole is assumed to have the crack. Two different crack sizes (2 and 4 mm) and two different orientations (0° and 135°) give a total of four different damage states. The Lamb wave in the steel panel is generated by imposing an in-plane radial displacement at point “A” with five-cycle short pulse signal having Gaussian envelope with a central frequency of 250 kHz. The FEM calculations are performed for the damage-free state to obtain the “Baseline signal”. Then the calculations are repeated for the cracked panel by introducing a crack of size 2 mm radiating out of the rivet hole H2 at 0° and 135° orientations measured from the vertical axis. Then the calculations are repeated for the 4-mm crack for the same two orientations. The ultrasonic signals thus obtained were processed using various signal-processing techniques discussed earlier—STFT, WT, WVD, HHT, CWD and ST. The damage-sensitive features are extracted from these joint time–frequency–energy spectra and then plugged into the DP expression. As stated earlier, the DP measures the deviation from the baseline signal. The DP has been defined such that it returns to zero numerical value if there is no damage, that is, when the recorded signal from the specimen matches with the baseline signal. A MATLAB code is written for first obtaining the joint time–frequency–energy distribution of the recorded signals and then to calculate the DP. The signals were recorded at four different locations, namely, S1, S2, S3, and S4, whose coordinates are given in inch as S1 (0.5, 3.5), S2 (6, 3.5), S3 (12, 3.5), and S4 (17.5, 3.5), or in millimeter as S1 (12.7, 88.9), S2 (152.4, 88.9), S3 (304.8, 88.9), and S4 (444.5, 88.9) respectively. For both healthy and damaged plates, the signals were recorded at the same locations. A typical ultrasonic signal recorded at location S1 is shown in Figure 3. Figure 4 shows how the ultrasonic energy spreads through the plate after it is generated at the actuator position.

caption.p: Typical ultrasonic signal recorded at location S1.

Ultrasonic wave propagation in the steel bridge connection plate containing a crack at the central hole oriented at 0° (or the north direction) (a and b) and 135° (or the south-east direction) (c and d), at time 0.18 µs (a and c) and at time 0.32 µs (b and d).

sec.p: The joint time–frequency–energy representations were obtained and shown in Figure 5 using the six different signal-processing techniques discussed above. The ultrasonic signal recorded at position S1 was shown in Figure 3. A total of 20 wave signals were collected, which includes four damage states and one healthy state of the structure at four locations.

caption.p: Time–frequency representation for ultrasonic signals recorded at S1 (0.5,3.5) using (a) short-time Fourier transform, (b) continuous wavelet transform, (c) Wigner–Ville distribution transform, (d) Hilbert–Huang transform, (e) Choi–Williams distribution transform, and (f) S-transform.

sec.p: The joint time–frequency–energy distributions were obtained for all wave signals to extract the damage-sensitive features from all 120 energy spectra. The ultrasonic signal in Figure 3 shows the first arrival of the S0 wave packet, followed by the A0 mode and multiply reflected signals.

When the crack is oriented at 0° direction, the problem is symmetric with respect to the central line; then the ultrasonic wave field also shows symmetry about the central line. However, when the crack is oriented at 135° direction the problem geometry is no longer symmetric. This fact is very useful in detecting the crack’s orientation relative to the rivet hole. This can be achieved by placing two sensors symmetrically about the central line. For a perfectly symmetric problem, the two sensors should show identical responses but if a crack is present at any location of the central hole other than the 0° or 180° directions the two sensors will not detect identical signals. This fact has been discussed further while quantifying the damage from the DP.

The energy spectra at frequencies 125, 250, and 500 kHz were extracted from the TFR and fed into the DP calculations. The DP was calculated from the signals recorded at locations S1, S2, S3, and S4 for all cracked plate configurations. Figure 6 shows the DP plots obtained from all six signal-processing techniques for the four damaged states. The consistency, reliability, and the effectiveness of the FE technique for crack’s characterization on the basis of its size and orientation are judged based on whether (1) the symmetry about central line can be predicted, (2) the effect of crack’s size can be predicted, (3) the effect of crack’s orientation can be addressed, and (4) a consistent pattern is present and so on. The actuator is positioned on the central line at location A and the sensor data is gathered with two sensors (S1 and S2) on the left and two sensors (S3 and S4) on the right side of the central hole H2. It can be observed that when there is no crack, or when the crack is oriented in the 0° direction then the problem configuration is symmetric about the central line. When the crack is oriented on either right or left of the central line then the symmetry condition is violated and the wave reflections from the crack surface affect the wave pattern uniquely. These expected trends in the results form a premise to evaluate capability of various signal-processing tools. In addition to this, it would be interesting to see if sensors (S2 and S3) located near the crack (but not too close, about 7.62 cm from the hole H2) are better in detecting cracks than the sensors (S1 and S4) located far away (22.85 cm from the hole H2). The DP values obtained from various signal-processing techniques are compared and judged on the basis of premise mentioned above. The technique that substantiates the aforementioned premise will be a desirable technique for the analysis of the present problem. The location of sensors is one critical parameter in the SHM. To study the effect of crack’s presence on received ultrasonic wave fields at various locations, the distribution of the DP along the line passing through sensors S1, S2, S3, and S4 is shown in Figure 6. Six advanced techniques—STFT, WT, CWD, WVD, ST, and HHT—are examined concurrently. A central line is drawn in all plots of Figure 6 to examine whether symmetry exists about this middle line. It is observed that although almost all six techniques confirm the premise, for STFT, CWD, ST, and HHT, the symmetric patterns are stronger.

caption.p: Damage parameter variations along the plate length (0–18 in) for all four damage configurations using six different signal-processing techniques.
STFT: short-time Fourier transform; WT: wavelet transform; CWD: Choi–Williams distribution transform; WVD: Wigner–Ville distribution transform; ST: S-transform; HHT: Hilbert–Huang transform.

sec.p: In a general consensus from all techniques, the DP values obtained from sensors S2 and S3 show higher values for 135° orientation of crack as compared to 0° oriented crack irrespective of the crack size (2 or 4 mm). However, this result is not true for the DP values obtained from sensors S1 and S4. This shows that the sensors S2 and S3 are better for capturing the crack orientation information compared to S1 and S4.

Another interesting fact observed in Figure 6 is that for 0° crack orientation the STFT and WT fail to give crack size information if the sensor signals are collected by sensors S2 and S3 that are closer to the crack. However, signals from sensors S1 and S4 give good information on crack size even with STFT and WT. Other techniques, such as CWD, WVD, ST, and HHT did not encounter such difficulty. For 0° orientation of the crack from STFT, WT, and ST-based analysis, the DP value decreases for a of crack size of 2 mm and increases for a crack size of 4 mm as the sensor location moves away from the crack. This trend is contradicted by the WVD- and HHT-based analyses where DP value increases as the sensor location moves away from the crack irrespective of the crack size (2 or 4 mm). The CWD shows no significant change in DP values as the sensor location moves away from the crack for 0° oriented crack. For 135° oriented crack, all techniques except the ST showed a general asymmetry about the central line. The CWD- and WVD-based analyses showed smaller DP values for sensor locations S3 and S4 as compared to the DP value for sensor locations S1 and S2 irrespective of the crack size.

In summary, this study demonstrates the suitability of six candidate FE tools to extract representational features out of ultrasonic signals—sensitive to a radial crack on a rivet hole in a joint panel of a bridge structure. All FE tools have their advantages and limitations. Therefore, no single FE tool can be claimed to be most suitable for all types of problem geometries and recorded signals. However, a comprehensive understanding of an existing damage can be assured with greater detail if the selected FE tools are applied sequentially on raw time series data. The proposed process can help in verifying any particular damage characteristic in multiple ways. In most practical problems, we frequently come across time-dependent signals that are of nonstationary nature where the frequency content changes rapidly as a function of time. The contribution of this study is in identifying the sequence in which a signal can be passed through the FE tools to effectively extract the crack size information along with its orientation information. To begin with, a signal can be passed through the STFT that may work best to signals if the passed signal has frequency contents well separated from each other in time domain. In the next step of the sequence, the signal can be passed through the WT that provides better time–frequency resolution for very common signal types where high spectral content appears only for short durations and low spectral component for long durations. Next, the signal is passed into the ST, which is an improvement over the STFT with modulating sinusoids fixed in time axis and scalable localizing Gaussian window moves and dilate. The ST tool provides absolute phase information due to the fact that the reference point is always fixed at origin in time axis. Then, in the next step of sequence, the signal can be passed into a different class of FE tools—WVD that does not show difficulty of trade-off between time–frequency resolutions and can reveal damage-sensitive aspects that may be distorted by the STFT or WT because of the lack in good temporal as well as spectral resolution. The next step forward in the sequence is to pass the signal through the CWD that is an improvement over the WVD with suppressed cross-term through convolution of a kernel function, which is a major drawback of the WVD. Next, the signal can be passed through the HHT that suits the nonstationary type of signals best, ensuring well-defined frequency and energy at any instant of time in the original signal.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The Lamb wave–based damage detection technique is developed to detect localized cracks in a steel bridge panel. The wave field is simulated for both cracked and uncracked plates by the FEM using commercial software COMSOL Multi-Physics. The state-of-the-art signal-processing tools are used for extracting damage-sensitive features from the transient ultrasonic signals received at various locations on the steel plate section and have been used to quantify the damage by a single quantity called “damage parameter.” The dependence of the DP value on the crack’s size and orientation has been demonstrated.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research was partially supported by a research grant from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) by Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of South Carolina.

ref.citation: AlleyneDN CawleyP (1992a) Optimization of Lamb wave inspection techniques. NDT & E International 25(1): 11–22.
